case_name: Petitions Nos. 97, 97A, 44 and 85 of 1956 (Pannalal Binjraj & Ors.)

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 filed by Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, oil mill owners, merchants and commission agents at Sahibganj with branch at 94, Lower Chitpur Road, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners and Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, oil mill owners, merchants and companymission agents, carrying on business at Sahibganj in the district of Santhal Parganas, having their branch at 94, Lower Chitpur Road, Calcutta, petitioner No. 1, and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, resident of the same place and erstwhile Karta of the Hindu undivided family, which carried on business in the name and style of Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, Petitioner No. 2.

facts.text: Before 28th September 1954, petitioners in Nos. 97 and 97A assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

anchor.surface_text: Before 28th September, 1954, they were being assessed by the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Patna.

facts.text: On 28th September 1954, Central Board of Revenue transferred cases of petitioners Nos. 97 and 97A to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: On 28th September, 1954, the Central Board of Revenue made an order transferring their cases to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle XI, Calcutta.

facts.text: On 22nd January 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 2 to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On 22nd January, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred the cases of petitioner No. 2 to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi,

facts.text: On 12th July 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred case of petitioner No. 1 to Income-tax Officer, Central Circle VI, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and on 12th July, 1955, it similarly transferred the cases of petitioner No. 1 to the same officer.

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No. 44 of 1956 is Shri A. L. Sud, sole proprietor of Messrs. Amritlal Sud Construction, residing in Calcutta since 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in Petition No. 44 of 1956 is Shri A. L. Sud, the sole proprietor of Messrs. Amritlal Sud  Construction  who originally belonged to Hoshiarpur district in the State of Punjab but has since 1948 been residing and carrying on business in Calcutta.

facts.text: Prior to 29th June 1955, A. L. Sud assessed by Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to 29th June, 1955, he had been assessed to income-tax by the Income-tax Officer, Special Survey Circle VII, Calcutta.

facts.text: On 29th June 1955, Central Board of Revenue transferred A. L. Sud's case to Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: On 29th June, 1955, the Central Board of Revenue transferred his cast to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, and the said officer companytinued the proceedings in the transferred case and also instituted further proceedings against the petitioner

facts.text: Amritsar group cases transferred on or about June 29 1953 from ITO A Ward Amritsar to ITO Special Circle Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: their cases were transferred on or about June 29, 1953, from the Income-tax Officer, A Ward. Amritsar, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Amritsar.

facts.text: Petitioner in No. 158 of 1956 Shri Ram Saran Das Kapur, karta of HUF at Amritsar, case transferred in 1954 to ITO Special Circle Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: His case also which, prior to the order companyplained against, was being entertained by the Income-tax Officer, F Ward, Amritsar, was transferred on some date in 1954 by an order of the Commissioner of Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Amritsar.

facts.text: Sriram Jhabarmull group: Nandram Agarwalla sole proprietor business at Kalimpong with branch Calcutta, transfers on March 15 1946, June 8 1946, July 27 1946 under s.5(7A).

anchor.surface_text: On March 15, 1946, the cases of the petitioner were transferred from the Income-tax Officer, Jalpaiguri, Darjeeling, to the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle I, Calcutta... on 8th June, 1946... on 27th July, 1946, orders were passed by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Central, Calcutta, under section 5  7A

facts.text: Raichur group: Kalloor Siddanna business in Raichur, transfer on 21st December 1953 by CIT Hyderabad to ITO Special Circle Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: On 21st December, 1953, however, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, issued a numberification under section 5  7A ordering that the case of the petitioner should be transferred from the Additional Income-tax Officer, Raichur, to the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Hyderabad.

facts.text: Another transfer for Raichur group shortly before 19th May 1955 back to ITO Raichur.

anchor.surface_text: It appears, however, that shortly before 19th May, 1955, the Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad, made another order under section 5  7A

issues.text: whether section 5(7A) of the Indian Income-tax Act, hereinafter called the Act, is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: section 5  7A  of the Indian Income-tax Act, hereinafter called the Act, is ultra vires the Constitution as infringing the fundamental rights enshrined in article 14 and article 19  1   g . The facts which led to the filing of the petitions may be shortly stated. Petitions Nos. 97 and 97A of 1956 The petitioners and Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, oil mill owners, merchants and companymission agents, carrying on business at Sahibganj in the district of Santhal Parganas, having their branch at 94, Lower Chitpur Road, Calcutta, petitioner No. 1, and R. B. Jamuna Das Chowdhury, resident of the same place and erstwhile Karta of the Hindu undivided family, which carried on business in the name and style of Messrs. Pannalal Binjraj, Petitioner No. 2.

issues.text: whether the transfer orders made under section 5(7A) are omnibus wholesale orders containing within the mischief of Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India and Others and therefore invalid

anchor.surface_text: The next point of attack is that the orders which were made by the Commissioner of Income-tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, in these petitions are omnibus wholesale orders of transfer companying within the mischief of Bidi Supply Co. v. Union of India and Others and are, therefore, hit by the majority judgment in that case.

issues.text: whether the specific orders of transfer under section 5(7A) in the various groups of petitions are discriminatory or mala fide and an abuse of power

anchor.surface_text: though in regard to each group there are several questions of fact involving the companysideration of the discriminatory character of the specific orders passed therein which we shall deal with hereafter in their appropriate places.

issues.text: whether orders of transfer under section 5(7A) made prior to the commencement of the Constitution can be challenged as unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: article 13 of the Constitution has no retrospective effect and if, therefore, any action was taken before the companymencement of the Constitution in pursuance of the processions of any law which was a valid law at the time when such action was take, such action cannot be challenged

holdings.text: Section 5(7A) of the Act is not violative of article 14 of the Constitution and also does not impose any unreasonable restriction of the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that section 5 7A of the Act is number violative of article 14 of the Constitution and also does number impose any unreasonable restriction of the fundamental right to carry on trade or business enshrined in article 19  1   g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Power vested for administrative convenience and efficient tax collection; guided by Act's purpose; not arbitrary or unguided; reasonable classification based on exigencies; minor inconvenience not substantial discrimination.

holdings.text: The right conferred upon the assessee under section 64(1) and (2) of the Act is not an absolute right but is circumscribed by the exigencies of tax collection.

anchor.surface_text: the right, if any, conferred upon the assessee under section 64(1) and (2) of the Act is not an absolute right but is circumscribed by the exigencies of tax collection

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreting s.64 with Act's primary object of tax assessment and collection; supported by precedents like Dayaldas and Wallace Brothers; convenience yields to administrative needs.

holdings.text: The power under section 5(7A) is not a naked and arbitrary power but guided and controlled by the purpose of the Act, viz., assessment and collection of income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The power is guided and controlled by the purpose which is to be achieved by the Act itself, viz., the charge of income-tax, the assessment and collection thereof, and is to be exercised for the more convenient and efficient collection of the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion for transfers based on widespread activities, inter-related transactions; vested in high officials; presumption of proper exercise; abuse remediable separately.

holdings.text: Omnibus wholesale orders of transfer are saved by the explanation to section 5(7A) and are not unconstitutional and void.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that the omnibus wholesale orders of transfer made against the petitioners by the Commissioner of Income-tax or the Central Board of Revenue, as the case may be, are saved by the explanation to section 5 7A and are number unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation expands 'case' to include all pending and future proceedings; dispels Bidi Supply mischief; proper construction allows comprehensive transfers without reissuing notices.

holdings.text: Orders of transfer under section 5(7A) made prior to the Constitution cannot be challenged as unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: article 13 of the Constitution has no retrospective effect and if, therefore, any action was taken before the commencement of the Constitution in pursuance of the provisions of any law which was a valid law at the time when such action was take, such action cannot be challenged

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 13(1) nullifies inconsistent laws prospectively; pre-Constitution valid actions under then-valid law unaffected; precedents like Keshavan Madhavan Menon.

holdings.text: Specific transfer orders in the petitions are not discriminatory, mala fide or abuse of power.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to these circumstances [...] it is clear that the transfer [...] were made as a matter of administrative convenience only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit evidence shows transfers for workload balancing, evasion investigations, inter-related cases; no inconvenience as hearings at assessee's convenience; acquiescence in some groups.

holdings.text: It would be prudent if principles of natural justice are followed before transfer orders under section 5(7A), where circumstances permit.

anchor.surface_text: it would be prudent if the principles of natural justice are followed, where circumstances permit, before any order of transfer under section 5(7A) of the Act is made by the Commissioner of Income-tax or the Central Board of Revenue

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not mandatory but advisable for notice, hearing, reasons; contrasts with s.64(3); aids bona fides scrutiny; except where object frustrated.

holdings.text: The petitions are dismissed as there is no substance in them.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that there is no substance in these petitions and they should be dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings uphold s.5(7A) and specific orders; no constitutional violation or abuse found.
